title: Will legislation permitting electric utilities to recover 2018 wildfire liability debt costs by charging customers become law in California before 14 October 2019?
preds: Confirmation of previous forecasts. Nothing new has occurred to change this.
It's California--one of the most corporate states in the Union.

I believe this "became law" as AB 1054 in July.
https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB1054

I find available information about this question vague. The governor signed legislation in July, but as far as I can tell, it requires approval by a commission that looks like it won't meet until the 21st.
Not going to happen in the time left. Finally, I am learning not to leave a forecast until the last day to update it. I'm sure four days will be much more of an impact on my score than just one...
Oct 13 is the final day of the year the Governor can sign Bills into laws, worth watching up until then.

https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB1054- Everything in the currently passed bill moves forward from 2019. https://www.kdrv.com/content/news/California-governor-signs-22-bills-aimed-at-reducing-wildfire-devastation-562093011.html- Oct 2nd 2019
I'm basically free riding on this one. Time appears to have effectively run out for a bill to be passed by Oct 14.
Late in updating this to 0%, no bill was up nor passed that would do this during the September session. Thus nothing can take effect prior to the deadline

Between time elapsed and the fact that a new bill meant to address the issue doesn't do this, I'm thinking chances are slim to none at this point. https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/California-lawmakers-advance-major-utility-14080228.php

The utility companies will instead participate in a fund that will (allegedly) offset the costs to raising the consumer's bill. 
https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-07-25/california-utilities-agree-to-pay-10-5-billion-into-new-wildfire-fund
I found nothing today in the 16 items related to CA wildfire liability legislation that indicates any are being forwarded for Governor's signature.
It appears that AB 1054 doesn't satisfy this claim and chances of something else passing in this time frame seems unlikely.
No news or updates on this

Originally misread the question.
Not  finding anything specific on 2018 liability - I've asked my state senator to identify any pending AB or SB bills that are in conference or otherwise specific to the 2018 liabilities, as well as tools for further leg. research. In the meantime - CA Assembly is presently on recess and resumes Sep 3, Members have only until Sep 6 to amend bills on the floor, and only until Sep 13 for any bill to be passed, Legislature reconvenes Jan 6 2020. Doesn't look like enough legislative time to do anything. Given the furor over the passing of SB 901 (Brown) and AB 1054 (Newsom) - I don't find any legislative imperative to "rush to judgment" . All litigation claims relating to 2018 currently remain suspended while PG&E in BK--- resulting in even less pressure on legislators to act in 2019. Finally - BK#1 took 3 years. The same law firms are handling BK#2. Large NY hedge funds all over the matter this time - having purchased both the debt and the equity - and submitting different plans for re-org. So you've got practiced legal players and big financial players all pushing for a path forward. But for any emergence to happen -this 2018 liability question has to be affirmatively answered.
Thus - this seems destined to be a 2020 legislative issue.

I have AB 1054 and a summary of AB 111 up on the screen.
They were both passed and signed into law on July 12, with both to take effect immediately.
Trick question?
Have I missed something?
people are still upset the power company failed to act to prevent the wildfires and I doubt it will pass before October 14
Dropping a bit as California seems to be pursuing alternative legal arrangements. https://www.climateliabilitynews.org/2019/07/25/residents-say-california-wildfire-liability-law-unconstitutional/
Utilities will not be allowed to recover liability, but may be able to collect other "costs" which will be used to pay debt,
If they can, they will, Fairness won’t come into it

The utilities are needed by everyone and the utilities have the legislative and political clout to work in their favor.  It is cheaper for them to run a advertising campain for their own support once than to pay additional costs yearly without bonds for wildfire liabilities!
Because the rate of wildfires their equipment cause will outway the losses from the fires they start.
Because California will still be burning then.
makes sense for 2018 as well otherwise wasted time
Reviewed bills of pending status for the August debate session, none appear to pertain to this forecast. Thus extremizing towards a No resolution

Savior legislation is rare and PGE is judged to be the cause of the 2018 Camp Fire, making savior leg unpopular.  And they do not need this savior legislation to raise prices.  existing legislation specifies 2017 and 2019 and excludes 2018.
Yes. It makes sense. California is actually trying to do something about the Environment

Adjusting given the verbiage of AB 1054 & the analysis of the bill (I attempted to break it down in order to get a more precise answer about whether or not the wildfire fund would be applicable retroactively, but was unable to find the specific passages I wanted). Common reporting however gives the effective date as only being post-confirmation of the funds creation. In addition, I don't foresee additional legislation being proposed & passed prior to October 14th (Bill would have to be proposed & passed prior to September 13th). Thus lowering my forecast (18↓)

Seems less likely with recent passage of AB 1054 which creates a $10B or $21B liquidity fund (depending on which utilities opt in: SoCal Edison, SDG&E). Though this does not apply to 2018 fires, it seems less likely that California legislators would help utilities recover funds for 2018 fires from ratepayers with a rate hike after passing this legislation which appears to have staved off a looming downgrade of the utilities credit ratings.

Current bill in legislature does not seem to provide payment of debt incurred in 2018. But, the fact that the legislation is moving forward to Assembly allows for the chance of a modified bill that could provide for that debt relief.

Proposed bill doesn't allow utilities to charge higher rates in order to pay for 2018 wildfires liabilities. Am I missing something? "Newsom’s plan would take $10.5 billion from California ratepayers to help utilities pay wildfire costs. The bill requires utilities to pay claims for 2017 and 2018 wildfires without raising rates for their customers in order to access the fund."
https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-gavin-newsom-wildfire-damages-plan-20190708-story.html "PG&E would be barred from participating in the fund until it pays 2017 and 2018 wildfire claims and emerges from bankruptcy without raising rates for its customers, officials said."
https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-gavin-newsom-wildfire-utility-fund-20190621-story.html "The marquee component of AB1054 is a new wildfire fund that would help PG&E and the Southern California utilities if their power lines are involved in more conflagrations. PG&E could access the fund only if it resolves its current wildfire claims and exits bankruptcy protection by June 30 of next year."
https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/California-s-big-PG-E-wildfire-bill-What-you-14079341.php
Government, especially in California, always favors business over consumers.

Legislation has now passed the California Senate. 
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-gavin-newsom-wildfire-damages-plan-20190708-story.html%3foutputType=amp
Given the short time span and little recent action. Though, it does seem necessary eventually.

The litigation against the utilitiy companies is valid.  So-Cal Edison neglected its infrastructure for decades in order to produce profits for shareholders.  The privately owned utilities should be bankrupted, dissolved and put under government management.  
But this will not happen.  In the end, it looks like the taxpayers will be bailing out the corporate malfeasants.

Suspect bonds are more likely than rate increases, but it will depend upon finding that PG&E was not responsible for the fires. No government would readily allow a utility that create the problem to have their customers bail them out of it.
big business always win and passes the cost on
Likely.  There is no limit to the degree that corporations can get away with murder.
Too much political sensitivity to the losses of victims to be seen supporting PGE at election time
Legislature will not act on it.  They look headed in creating a liability fund rather than inverse condemnation.

(4↓) Word from the California lawmaker discussions today show little movement on the issue of wildfire liability in either direction. Multiple avenues are still firmly on the table, but direct changes to ratepayer protections do not appear to be among them. Again likely to have another update by the end of the week on this issue.
Likely drawn out with not much legislation over summer months

Update expected tomorrow evening, at this point I'm reducing my weighting on whether or not a bill of this type may happen to the likelihood that it goes in as an October 1st effective law & not a January 1st effective law. I think it's highly unlikely that a viable bill could make it through in time unless something is proposed in the next couple of weeks, thus any announcement tomorrow by the state legislature/governor's office will sway my forecast dramatically.
got a message from a friend who channel's Harry Bridges
CA always pushes the costs to their citizens.

He will be leaving his governorship one day.
Have to keep prospects open
I do not see this as possible given California politics.
Of course. Rather than taking money from the shareholders for poorly maintained power lines that caused the wild fires they screw consumers. Bad idea.
It is bondholders versus ratepayers.  Rate payers vote.  No one likes pge so there is no path to this becoming law.

Forgot to actually type in the new forecast #... (slaps forehead) To reiterate, adjusting down to original forecast (7↓) until further news comes forward (in particular the post strike-team conclusions). Expecting something this week.

Adjusting (7↑) after reviewing proposals put forward in the Strike Force's report released a couple weeks back & after reviewing the open ended phrasing of the question. Some of the proposals put forward would technically allow for utilities to recover funds from 2018 fires, though such allowance would be incidental to implementing these recommendations, not instrumental within them. AKA implementing their recommendations would allow for the possibility of fund recovery from 2018 fires by increasing rates, but would not in itself allow for utilities to immediately do so (i.e. fault-based standard). Report: https://www.gov.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Wildfires-and-Climate-Change-California%E2%80%99s-Energy-Future.pdf
very liberal policies in California put the onus on the customers in at risk locations
Given the consumer protection bias in the state of California, I consider it unlikely the legislation will pass
Haven't done any research on this whatsoever, but based on the question it seems like a logical outcome. Notwithstanding the tight timeframe however...
This what a non government regulated industry does as common practice.

(1) I really don't understand this question. Why is there a need? Companies can already raise their prices by saying expenditures have risen by so & so. And, so, charge more. Or, just apply to whatever authority for price increase. No need for a new law.
(2) California is a very progressive state. People will howl over other avenues not explored. Worse comes to worse, the state can provide some compensation. I.e., the state is in a better position to deal with the companies rather than individual customers.
The principle has already been approved, this is just another detail.
it is election year, increasing prices does not look good

A bill must be in print 30 days before moving through legislation. Chris Holden had such a bill drafted in November, but it hasn’t been introduced yet because of controversy. So it only has 5.5 months, until September 14th, to be introduced in time. Yet PG&E has filed bankruptcy, and the gov called for a commission plan by April 12th, though the deadline is July 1st. Let’s guess it arrives in between, mid-May, leaving 4 months to pass a bill by the deadline. By the following news article, the Governor of CA has indicated that liability standards will be changed favorably for PG&E, making stock prices jump almost 8x from $3/share to $23/share. It seems almost certain (98%) that the forecasted change will happen, and the question is whether it will occur by the deadline.  https://www.google.com/url?rct=j&sa=t&url=https://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article229153379.html&ct=ga&cd=CAEYACoUMTU0ODM1NDAxNTUzMDQ1OTM5NTIyGjIzZmU4NWZkYWM1YjQ0NWE6Y29tOmVuOlVT&usg=AFQjCNG1OZJplLCy4mWKOfJHOlxWgqHtZA They could have voted on this in December and have dragged on now for 5 months. The governor's statement and general tone of "let's get this done" makes me think it's only 15% likely they'll drag on past the deadline.  Let’s say a 98% chance of bailout times 85% chance of timely passage equals 83% chance of passage by October.
This will become law, the question is how quickly.
Without this CA customers might lose electricity
Sound like something a Liberal would dream up and California is full of them.

It is already in existing legislation -- This bill would increase the maximum penalty to $100,000. The bill would prohibit an electrical corporation from recovering a fine or penalty through a rate approved by the PUC, and would make related nonsubstantive changes. This bill would authorize the PUC, in an application by an electrical corporation to recover costs and expenses arising from a catastrophic wildfire, to allow cost recovery if the costs and expenses are just and reasonable, based on the PUC’s consideration of the conduct of the electrical corporation and relevant information submitted into the PUC’s record, including, but not limited to, information regarding specified factors.
(10) Existing law prohibits an electrical corporation or gas corporation, for a period of 5 years following a safety violation causing more than $5,000,000 in ratepayer liability, as specified, from recovering from ratepayers expenses for annual compensation of an officer in excess of $1,000,000 without PUC approval. Existing law requires the electrical corporation or gas corporation seeking to pay, or seeking recovery of, annual officer compensation in excess of $1,000,000 during that 5-year period to file an application with the PUC containing specified information. Existing law requires the PUC, following a duly noticed public hearing in a proceeding to consider the application, to issue a written decision on the application.
This bill would repeal the above provisions relating to excess annual compensation of utility officers. The bill would prohibit an electrical corporation or gas corporation from recovering from ratepayers any annual salary, bonus, benefits, or other consideration of any value, paid to an officer of the electrical corporation or gas corporation, and would require that compensation to instead be funded solely by shareholders of the electrical corporation or gas corporation
Californians unlikely to be sympathetic to PG&E's troubles.
Unlikely as the cost will be too high

Little tend to happen after an event has occured, as something else will be top-of-the mind for the population and politicians. I don't see the chances of this happening to be large, unless a new event will occur.
To many distractions to focus on this issue

Although it maybe passed I believe it will take longer than timeframe set, ie Congress passing legislation and utility companies filing for bankruptcy will drag it out as long as possible in an effort to recover
The liability must be converted. However a small but significant number will oppose additional liabilty
It’s beyond the responsibility of the local owners to enact change of such a degree to alter the landscape and environmental location.
Too politically fraught  to side with the fire starters.
This would be very unpopular with voters, but I think the pressure put on politicians from said utility companies would make it close.
Its California! They care about their people. Their land and the eco system. They will charge because that people would not mind paying.

There are three ways to pay for natural disasters: taxpayers, ratepayers, and stockholders.  You have to completely wipe out stockholders to raise anywhere near the cost of the "Camp" fire.  The new utility, post bankruptcy, will need money from ratepayers or taxpayers.  Sooner or later it's the ratepayers, like me, who will have to pay the costs.  If it wasn't political the chances of ratepayers footing the bill would be 99.9%.  Given that it is political, and the crowd forecast is 31%, I'll go as high as 51%.

A bill must be in print 30 days before moving through legislation. Chris Holden had such a bill drafted in November, but it hasn’t been introduced yet because of controversy. So it only has 5.5 months, until September 14th, to be introduced in time. Yet PG&E has filed bankruptcy, and the gov called for a commission plan by April 12th, though the deadline is July 1st. Let’s guess it arrives in between, mid-May, leaving 4 months to pass a bill by the deadline. It seems 90% likely that extending SB 901 would be the solution. It seems like a finding that PG&E was not responsible for the Camp Fire would make passage of such a bill more viable. It seems 10% likely that PG&E is not at fault. So increase the chance to 91%. It took 3 months after containment to complete the Tubbs Fire investigation, but it had been 4 months since Camp Fire containment. I expect they will determine cause by next month. The big question is how quickly they’ll move after receiving recommendations, and whether the committee will drag its feet. They could have voted on this in December and have dragged on now for 5 months. I could see maybe a 25% chance of the legislature fighting for 4 months after seeing the recs and results of investigation. Let’s say a 91% chance of bailout times 75% chance of timely passage equals 68% chance of passage by October.

I can't find any indication of momentum behind this idea in the past 6 weeks. It strikes me that there are other alternatives that avoid state control.  There are three possibilities:  1) this outcome 2) another resolution before October 3) no resolution before October. I think they are listed in increasing order of likelihood. I would put the odds quite a bit lower but respecting the consensus which seems higher, particularly given limited knowledge on my part.

Ultimately looks like this will come down to the conclusions drawn by Gov. Newsom & the "strike team" he put together (https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-newsom-pge-bankruptcy-plan-20190212-story.html). Given Newsom's tone toward PG&E historically (assertive but friendly) and of late (condescendingly assertive) I would lean towards very unlikely (30-40%). Given the above timeline I would drift towards the bottom of that range, so I'll settle for now at 34%
Dumb money moving higher.. If 2001-era history repeats, judicial approval of bailout (via rate payers) is probable, but unlikely to finish until early 2021.
How does PG&E pay for the damages otherwise? Also, Oct 14 feels a little random, do they know something we don't?
There ar no alternatives to the funding of PG&E, to get them out of bankruptcy
The politics are right for it.
Miraculous recovery in PG&E stock (PCG) says it all, the hedge fund + Sacramento fix is in.

The sums are staggering and the costs to the consumer would be massive, even spread out over a large population like California. If negligence is shown near the seats of the main fires, why should consumers pay for corporate negligence? Brown is already warning  everyone that fires are  'new normal' but unless he sees a way to control energy costs, California could be priced out of some industries - and hitech industries are big power users. High voltage power lines running over wilderness areas are a core probelm which could be solved by more distributed power generation (e.g. local solar, heat pump etc) but even so, dried out forest is flammable. Where would the negligence suits go then?

PG&E is largely friendless, except for such folks as are stuck with a stake in the firm.   Such folks tend not to be poor and powerless, though, at least compared to the mass of consumers.  I like @mpfred6 's number at the moment.

I'm not sure this question is worded properly.  The public utilities need  to operate and the only source of cash is ultimately the rate payers.  The real question is will the PUC force the equity holders to take a complete loss before the utilities can tap the bond markets. My answer is my weighting if whether the State will allow the shareholders of the public utilities to keep their equity while allowing them to issue bonds.
Unlikely legislation will be passed as consumers should not be held accountable for all the costs of the damages.
